properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Bucheen Creek, Cravensville and parts of the southern end of the Nariel Valley and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Bucheen Creek, Cravensville and parts of the southern end of the Nariel Valley and surrounds. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Bucheen Creek, Cravensville and parts of the southern end of the Nariel Valley and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire that started 27km West Of Walwa is not yet under control.
  • The fire started in the Mt Lawson State Park on the 5th January and has spread through to the Wabba Wilderness Park. 
  • The immediate fire threat has reduced. 
  • Storms and lightning have passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued 9:52am 31 January, 2026.
  • For the latest community newsletter click HERE.

If you left the area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Emergency services, machinery and aircraft will remain in the area.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • Monitor air quality and take precautions to protect your health by visiting https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/ 
  • For localised mental health support please contact Albury Wodonga Health Mental Health Triage Line on 1300 104 211
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 09:50 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

New fire starts are expected. - Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions. - This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued 9:52am 31 January, 2026. - For the latest community newsletter click HERE. If you left the area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards. What you should do: If you have not already left: - Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards. - If you have already left: - Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued. - Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Tatura .
  • There is a mulch heap fire at Bayunga Road and Midland Highway, Tatura. 
  • Mulch fires are not likely to spread into grassland, but can generate a lot of smoke. 
  • This fire may continue to burn for up to 2 days.
  • Firefighters are attending to this fire and it will continue to be monitored.
  • There is a southerly wind for the next 48 hours that is blowing smoke to the north across the Midland Highway. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to cal VicEmergency
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

Incident Location: Tatura
Issue Date: Saturday 31 January 2026, 12:17 pm
Next Update: Monday 02 February 2026, 10:10 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/41020/moreinfo

This Community Information is being issued for Tatura .
- There is a mulch heap fire at Bayunga Road and Midland Highway, Tatura. 
- Mulch fires are not likely to spread into grassland, but can generate a lot of smoke. 
- This fire may continue to burn for up to 2 days.
- Firefighters are attending to this fire and it will continue to be monitored.
- There is a southerly wind for the next 48 hours that is blowing smoke to the north across the Midland Highway. 
- Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities.


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Dargo, Waterford, Castleburn, Crooked River and surrounding areas
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Dargo, Waterford, Castleburn, Crooked River and surrounding areas.
  • The bushfire at Wonnangatta Valley (known as the Wonnangatta - Dargo complex) is now under control.
  • Firefighters are onsite to continue extinguishment of any remaining hotspots. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Find information on protecting yourself and your family by visiting CFA Plan and Prepare
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Aircraft are operating in the area. 
  • Firefighters continue patrolling this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
For more information on Park closure updates check the Parks Victoria website and the Forest Fire Management website.

For Current Road closures check the VicTraffic website or call 13 11 70
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 03/02/2026 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Gellibrand.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 6:58pm Wednesday 28 January.
  • The water at Gellibrand is not safe to drink.
  • Treated water storage levels have dropped and water pressure has reduced as a result of the bushfire in the area.
  • Further information can be found on the Barwon Water website.
Tap water is not safe to drink in Gellibrand. Boiling the tap water will not make it safe. 
What you should do: 
  • Do not drink tap water.
  • You should only drink bottled water. 
  • If you are unsure if the water is safe to drink, you should not drink it.
It is unsafe to use tap water for: 
  • Food preparation, cleaning food or preparing baby formula. 
  • Cleaning dishes.
  • Making ice, brushing teeth and preparing beverages.
  • Giving water to pets or animals - use bottled water instead.
Tap water can be used for:
  • Flushing toilets
  • Washing clothes
  • Showering
Maintaining personal hygiene: 
  • It is important to stay clean. 
  • Use hand sanitiser after going to the bathroom and before you consume food. 
  • Use disposable baby wipe products that are not soap based without water to clean yourself. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Drinking tap water in Gellibrand could lead to illness, especially for young children, the elderly, or people with weak immune systems. For personal health advice, please consult your medical practitioner and mention this notice.
  • Barwon Water has commenced an initial assessment of the damage and is planning the reinstatement of water services.
  • They have also commenced carting in water to top up the tank. This water is to connect households and businesses to supply for essential (non-drinking) needs such as flushing toilets and showering.
  • For information on requesting relief drinking water to top up tanks, go to Water Relief and Replacement.
This message was issued by Department of Health.  

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed:  
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.    
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - DRINKING WATER - Do Not Drink Tap Water Incident Location: Gellibrand Issue Date: Thursday 29 January 2026, 02:24 pm Next Update: Monday 02 February 2026, 05:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/40962/moreinfo This Advice is being issued for Gellibrand. - This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 6:58pm Wednesday 28 January. - The water at Gellibrand is not safe to drink. - Treated water storage levels have dropped and water pressure has reduced as a result of the bushfire in the area. - Further information can be found on the Barwon Water website. Tap water is not safe to drink in Gellibrand. Boiling the tap water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Karbethong, Lake View, Mallacoota.
  • The bushfire at Mallacoota - Lake Barracoota is now contained.
  • FFMVic crews continue to walk the perimeter of the fire searching for and extinguish hotspots.   
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
There is no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions, which may change.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Forest firefighters continue to suppress hotspots and monitor the fire during the hot weather over the weekend.
Parts of the Croajingolong National Park to the east of Mallacoota Inlet are closed including: 
  • Lakeview Track
  • Barracoota Link Track
  • Howe Flat Track and Howe Flat walking track
  • Cemetery Bight Day Visitor Area and jetty
  • Spotted Dog Mine walking track
  • Brokewells Hut jetty and Allans Head Day Visitor Area and jetty
  • The Wilderness Coast Walk to the east of Mallacoota is also temporarily closed.
Other forest roads to the north of the bushfire are closed.  Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Dartmouth, Lake Dartmouth and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire that started 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • The fire is currently burning in the Cravensville and Wabba Wilderness areas.
  • The immediate fire threat has reduced.
  • Storms and lightning have passed through the area overnight. New fire starts are expected.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued 31st January at 10:18am.
To view the latest Community Newsletter Click HERE
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Chesney Vale. 
  • The fire has been contained within the Mount Meg Conservation Reserve. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 5:20pm, Sunday 1 February.
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area:
  • Emergency services will remain in the area overnight to monitor the fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: Nariel Valley including McNamara Crossing, Staceys Bridge and surrounds.
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Nariel Valley including McNamara Crossing, Staceys Bridge and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire that started 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control. 
  •  The fire started in the Mt Lawson State Park on the 5th January and has spread through to the Wabba Wilderness Park. The fire is approximately 121,500 hectares.
  •  Firefighters have been able to contain the fire within its current boundary. 
  • Storms and lightning have passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act message issued 30 January at 10:26a1.
  • For the latest community newsletter click HERE.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • Defending a house requires: At least two fit and determined adults who are physically and mentally prepared to work long and hard in arduous and difficult conditions. At least 10,000 litres of water (not from mains supply which can fail during a fire). Protective clothing. Appropriate firefighting hoses and pumps.
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
The following road closures are in place:
  • The Murray Valley Highway is open between Granya Road and Cudgewa Valley Road. 
  • Side roads off the Murray Valley Highway, between Granya Road and Cravensville Road are closed.
  • Reduced speed limits are in place while emergency and essential services continue to work in the area.
  • Soils and structures on the side of roads will be unstable. Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.  
  • Normal school bus routes will resume from Monday 2 February, 2026.  
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Towong Shire Recovery Hubs   

Tallangatta 
34 Towong Street 
Tues, Wed, Thu - 10am-12pm   

Corryong 
Cnr Donaldson St and Towong Road 
Tues, Wed, Thu - 10am-12pm
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

The fire is approximately 121,500 hectares. - Firefighters have been able to contain the fire within its current boundary. - Storms and lightning have passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected. - This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act message issued 30 January at 10:26a1. - For the latest community newsletter click HERE. The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Gellibrand, Lovat, Barongarook West, Carlisle River, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Barongarook West, Carlisle River, Gellibrand, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren, Lovat. 
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is contained..
  • Smoke will be visible across the fire area and some hotspots may be present.
  • There will be hotspots identified within the impacted area, crews are actively managing these.
  • Crews are also patrolling the perimeter, extinguishing hotspots, undertaking hazardous tree assessments.
  • Firefighting aircraft continues to track fire activity and monitor impacted areas.
  • This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act - Threat is Reduced - Monitor Condtions issued at 5.20pm 31/01/2026.
  • People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area:
  • Traffic Management Points are in place - Residents only, Identification will be required.
  • Colac - Lavers Hill Road at Ferguson;
  • Colac - Lavers Hill Road and Campiglis Road;
  • Road closures:
  • Gellibrand - Carlisle Road is closed.
  • All Forest and National Park Tracks and Roads within the impacted area are closed.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.Emergency services will remain in the area.Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Threat Is Reduced
Incident Location: Carlisle River
Issue Date: Sunday 01 February 2026, 09:46 am
Next Update: Tuesday 03 February 2026, 09:50 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/41038/moreinfo

The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Barongarook West, Carlisle River, Gellibrand, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren, Lovat. 
- There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is contained..
- Smoke will be visible across the fire area and some hotspots may be present.
- There will be hotspots identified within the impacted area, crews are actively managing these.
- Crews are also patrolling the perimeter, extinguishing hotspots, undertaking hazardous tree assessments.
- Firefighting aircraft continues to track fire activity and monitor impacted areas. 
- This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act - Threat is Reduced - Monitor Condtions issued at 5.20pm 31/01/2026.



- People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities. 
- There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Tintaldra, Towong, Cudgewa, Corryong, Colac Colac, Thowgla, Biggara, Bunroy and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Tintaldra, Towong, Cudgewa, Corryong, Colac Colac, Thowgla, Biggara, Bunroy and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire at 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire started in the Mt Lawson State Park on the 5th January and has spread through to the Wabba Wilderness Park. The fire is approximately 121,500 hectares.
  • The immediate fire threat has reduced.
  • Storms and lightning has passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected.
  • For the latest community newsletter click HERE
  • This Advice replaces the Advice message issued at 9:26am 31 January, 2026.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Murray Valley Highway is open between Granya Road and Cudgewa Valley Road.
  • Side roads off the Murray Valley Highway, between Granya Road and Cravensville Road are closed.
  • Reduced speed limits are in place while emergency and essential services continue to work in the area.
  • Soils and structures on the side of roads will be unstable. Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions. 
  • Benambra-Corryong Road is open to local residents only.
  • Normal school bus routes will resume from Monday 2 February, 2026. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Towong Shire Recovery Hubs

Tallangatta
34 Towong Street
Tues, Wed, Thu - 10am-12pm

Corryong
Cnr Donaldson St and Towong Road
Tues, Wed, Thu - 10am-12pm
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

The fire is approximately 121,500 hectares. - The immediate fire threat has reduced. - Storms and lightning has passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected. - For the latest community newsletter click HERE - This Advice replaces the Advice message issued at 9:26am 31 January, 2026. There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Tom Groggin, the Benambra-Corryong Road east of Lake Dartmouth and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire that started 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • The fire started in the Mt Lawson State Park on the 5th January and has spread through to the Wabba Wilderness Park.
  • The immediate fire threat has reduced.
  • Storms and lightning have passed through the area over night. New fire starts are expected.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:09am 31 January, 2026. 
  • For the latest community newsletter click HERE
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.

  • The Benambra-Corryong Road is now open for local residents.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Kennedys Creek
  • This Advice replaces the Advice - Threat is reduced issued at 2.04pm 31/01/2026.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  • Traffic Management Points are in place - Residents only, Identification will be required.
  • Colac - Lavers Hill Road at Ferguson.
  • Colac - Lavers Hill Road and Campiglis Road.
  • Road closures:
  • Gellibrand - Carlisle Road is closed.
  • All Forest and National Park Tracks and Roads within the impacted area are closed.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2026 01:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
